greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Fourth 4-dimensional hyper-tetrahedral coordinate; 4-D analog of A056558.
comment: Alternatively, write n = C(i,4)+C(j,3)+C(k,2)+C(l,1) with i>j>k>l>=0; sequence gives k values. Each n >= 0 has a unique representation as n = C(i,4)+C(j,3)+C(k,2)+C(l.1) with i>j>k>l>=0. This is the combinatorial number system of degree t = 4, where we get [A194882, A194883, A194884, A127324].

If {(W,X,Y,Z)} are 4-tuples of nonnegative integers with W>=X>=Y>=Z ordered by W, X, Y and Z, then W=A127321(n), X=A127322(n), Y=A127323(n) and Z=A127324(n). These sequences are the four-dimensional analogs of the three-dimensional A056556, A056557 and A056558.
This is a 'Matryoshka doll' sequence with alpha=0 (cf. A055462 and A000332), seq(seq(seq(seq(i,i=alpha..k),k=alpha..n),n=alpha..m),m=alpha..4). - _Peter Luschny_, Jul 14 2009
reference: D. E. Knuth, The Art of Computer Programming, vol. 4A, Combinatorial Algorithms, Section 7.2.1.3, Eq. (20), p. 360.
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
mathematica: Table[i, {m, 0, 5}, {k, 0, m}, {j, 0, k}, {i, 0, j}] // Flatten  (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Sep 27 2011 *)
results.author: _Graeme McRae_, Jan 10 2007
